Authors: Han Z., Li Q., Sun S., Zhao W., Shi L.
Title: Inactivated Sendai virus strain Tianjin induces apoptosis and autophagy through reactive oxygen species production in osteosarcoma MG-63 cells
Affiliations: Department of Orthopedics, Tianjin hospital, Tianjin, China; Department of Pathogenic Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China; Department of Emergency & General Department, Stomatological Hospital of Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Han, Z., Department of Orthopedics, Tianjin hospital, Tianjin, China, Department of Pathogenic Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China; Li, Q., Department of Pathogenic Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China; Sun, S., Department of Pathogenic Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China; Zhao, W., Department of Emergency & General Department, Stomatological Hospital of Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China; Shi, L., Department of Pathogenic Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Tianjin Medical University, Tianjin, China
Abstract: Sendai virus strain Tianjin, a novel genotype of Sendai virus, has been proven to possess potent antitumor effect on certain cancer cell types although inactivated by ultraviolet (UV). This study was carried out to investigate the in vitro anticancer properties of UV-inactivated Sendai virus strain Tianjin (UV-Tianjin) on human osteosarcoma cells and the underlying molecular mechanism. Our studies demonstrated UV-Tianjin significantly inhibited the viability of human osteosarcoma cell lines and triggered apoptosis through activation of both extrinsic and intrinsic pathways in MG-63 cells. Meanwhile, autophagy occurred in UV-Tianjin-treated cells. Blockade of autophagy with 3-methyladenine remarkably attenuated the inhibition of cell proliferation by UV-Tianjin, suggesting that UV-Tianjin-induced autophagy may be contributing to cell death. Furthermore, UV-Tianjin induced reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, which was involved in the execution of MG-63 cell apoptosis and autophagy, as evidenced by the result that treatment of N-acetyl-L-cysteine, a ROS scavenger, attenuated both apoptosis and autophagy. In addition, inhibition of apoptosis promoted autophagy, whereas suppression of autophagy attenuated apoptosis. Our results suggest that UV-Tianjin triggers apoptosis and autophagic cell death via generation of the ROS in MG-63 cells, which might provide important insights into the effectiveness of novel strategies for osteosarcoma therapy. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: apoptosis; autophage; human osteosarcoma cells; reactive oxygen species (ROS); Sendai virus strain Tianjin

Authors: Zhan Q., Tian Y., Dai Y., Li Y., Li Y., Liu Y., Xue C., Wang J.
Title: Antarctic krill oil promotes longitudinal bone growth in adolescent male mice
Affiliations: College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhan, Q., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Tian, Y., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Dai, Y., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Li, Y., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Li, Y., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Liu, Y., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Xue, C., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China; Wang, J., College of Food Science and Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao, Shandong  266003, China
Abstract: The effects of dietary supplementation with Antarctic krill oil (AKO) on longitudinal bone growth in adolescent male Institute for Cancer Research (ICR) mice for 21 days were investigated. Histological results showed that AKO promoted longitudinal bone growth, increased skeletal mineral content and strength, enhanced entochondrostosis supported by higher longitudinal bone growth rate and growth plate height. Then, the potential mechanisms responsible for these observations were measured, results showed that AKO increased the secretion of the GH-IGF-1 pathway and entochondrostosis-related factors in serum increased the expression of IGF-1 in the liver and bone, which promoted proliferation and differentiation of chondrocytes, vascular invasion and bone formation related gene expression. AKO promoted longitudinal bone growth, using the GH-IGF-1 pathway, suggesting that AKO might be a potential functional food to improve growth potential of adolescents. © 2019
Author Keywords: Antarctic krill oil; Entochondrostosis; Euphausia superba; GH-IGF-1 axis pathway; Growth plate; Longitudinal bone growth

Authors: Rubio Y., Montiel O., Sepúlveda R.
Title: Quantum inspired algorithm for microcalcification detection in mammograms
Affiliations: Instituto Politécnico Nacional - CITEDI, Avenue Instituto Politécnico Nacional 1310, Nueva Tijuana, Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Rubio, Y., Instituto Politécnico Nacional - CITEDI, Avenue Instituto Politécnico Nacional 1310, Nueva Tijuana, Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico; Montiel, O., Instituto Politécnico Nacional - CITEDI, Avenue Instituto Politécnico Nacional 1310, Nueva Tijuana, Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico; Sepúlveda, R., Instituto Politécnico Nacional - CITEDI, Avenue Instituto Politécnico Nacional 1310, Nueva Tijuana, Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico
Abstract: This paper introduces a novel methodology based on quantum signal processing (QSP) and cellular automata (CA) to detect microcalcifications in mammograms. The methodology includes algorithms to detect microcalcification in binary and grayscale images. Essentially, quantum algorithms are used to improve edge detection results and CA are used to enhance the definition of the microcalcification in both groups of images. In grayscale images, CA are used to identify areas having a high probability of being microcalcifications. Benchmark images from the Mammographic Image Analysis Society (Mini-MIAS) digital mammogram database and the Digital Database for Screening Mammography (DDSM), which include mammograms showing several abnormalities previously evaluated by experts, were used in our study. Experiments using the two quantum processing algorithms were conducted, and the results were compared with those of other approaches for microcalcification detection. © 2018
Author Keywords: Breast cancer; Cellular automata; Mammograms; Microcalcifications; Quantum image processing; Quantum signal processing

Title: New knowledge about old drugs; a cardenolide type glycoside with cytotoxic effect and unusual secondary metabolites from Digitalis grandiflora Miller
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Hacettepe University, Sihhiye, Ankara, 06100, Turkey; Department of Pharmacognosy, Graduate School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nagoya City University, Nagoya, 467-8603, Japan; Laboratory of Medicinal Resources, School of Pharmacy, Aichi Gakuin University, Nagoya, 464-8650, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kutluay, V.M., Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Hacettepe University, Sihhiye, Ankara, 06100, Turkey; Makino, T., Department of Pharmacognosy, Graduate School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nagoya City University, Nagoya, 467-8603, Japan; Inoue, M., Laboratory of Medicinal Resources, School of Pharmacy, Aichi Gakuin University, Nagoya, 464-8650, Japan; Saracoglu, I., Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Hacettepe University, Sihhiye, Ankara, 06100, Turkey
Abstract: Phytochemical investigation of the aerial parts of Digitalis grandiflora Miller (Plantaginaceae) led to the isolation of an undescribed cardenolide type glycoside digigrandifloroside (1) along with five known compounds, rengyoside A (2), rengyoside B (3), cleroindicin A (4), salidroside (5), and cornoside (6), from its aqueous fraction of methanolic extract. Structures of the isolated compounds were determined by means of spectroscopic techniques. 1–6 were isolated for the first time from D. grandiflora. 2 and 3 are being reported for the first time from Digitalis genus and Plantaginaceae family with this study. This is the second report for occurrence of 4 from a Digitalis species. Cytotoxic activity of the aqueous fraction was also tested against HEp-2 (Human larynx epidermoid carcinoma) and HepG2 (Human hepatocellular carcinoma) cancer cell lines and L929 (Mouse fibroblast cell) non-cancerous cell line. Aqueous fraction showed stronger cytotoxicity on HEp-2 cells than HepG2. Therefore, the cytotoxic activity of 1, 2, 4, and 6 were tested against HEp-2 and L929 cell lines. 3 and 5 couldn't be tested due to their insufficient amount. 1 showed the highest cytotoxicity against HEp-2 cells with IC 50 value 10.1 μM when compared with the positive control, etoposide and 2–6 (IC 50 of etoposide; 39.5 μM). © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: antiproliferative activity; cardenolide glycosides; digigrandifloroside; Digitalis species; Plantaginaceae

Authors: Nezhad-Mokhtari P., Arsalani N., Javanbakht S., Shaabani A.
Title: Development of gelatin microsphere encapsulated Cu-based metal-organic framework nanohybrid for the methotrexate delivery
Source title: Journal of Drug Delivery Science and Technology
Affiliations: Polymer Research Laboratory, Department of Organic and Biochemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Faculty of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, G. C, P. O. Box 19396-4716, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Nezhad-Mokhtari, P., Polymer Research Laboratory, Department of Organic and Biochemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Arsalani, N., Polymer Research Laboratory, Department of Organic and Biochemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Javanbakht, S., Faculty of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, G. C, P. O. Box 19396-4716, Tehran, Iran; Shaabani, A., Faculty of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, G. C, P. O. Box 19396-4716, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: The purpose of the study is to the effective approach for the development of methotrexate (MTX) loaded as an anticancer drug into Cu-based metal-organic framework nanohybrid (Cu-MOF/MTX) inserted in pH-sensitive gelatin microsphere biopolymer (Cu-MOF/MTX@GM). MTX was loaded into two-dimensional tunnels and the empty face-centered cubic lattice of Cu-MOF porous. The developed Cu-MOF/MTX@GM was characterized using FTIR, SEM, and XRD analysis. In vitro drug release was demonstrated through the comparison of the simulated physiological conditions and tumor tissue environment for illustrating the MTX release ability of the obtained novel microspheres. Furthermore, the cytotoxicity of the MTX-loaded Cu-MOF @GM is examined by MTT assay using the human breast epithelial adenocarcinoma (MCF-7) cell lines, and the results revealed that the carrier was suitable as an anticancer drug targeting. According to the obtained results, the developed carrier has promising qualities as an excellent candidate for target delivery of MTX to cancer tissues. © 2019
Author Keywords: Controlled release; Gelatin microsphere; Metal-organic framework; Methotrexate; Targeted drug delivery

Authors: Tan Z., Kang T., Zhang X., Tong Y., Chen S.
Title: Nerve growth factor prevents arsenic-induced toxicity in PC12 cells through the AKT/GSK-3β/NFAT pathway
Affiliations: Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Tan, Z., Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Kang, T., Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zhang, X., Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Tong, Y., Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Chen, S., Department of Oncology, Xin Hua Hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The potential risk of arsenic-related neurodegeneration has been a growing concern. Arsenic exposure has been reported to disrupt neurite growth and neuron body integrity in vitro; however, its underlying mechanism remains unclear. Previously, we showed that arsenic sulfide (AS) exerted cytotoxicity in gastric and colon cancer cells through regulating nuclear factor of the activated T cells (NFAT) pathway. The NFAT pathway regulates axon path finding and neural development. Using neural crest cell line PC12 cells as a model, here we show that AS caused mitochondrial membrane potential collapse, reactive oxygen species production, and cytochrome c release, leading to mitochondria-mediated apoptosis via the AKT/GSK-3β/NFAT pathway. Increased glycogen synthase kinase-3 beta (GSK-3β) activation leads to the inactivation of NFAT and its antiapoptotic effects. Through inhibiting GSK-3β activity, both nerve growth factor (NGF) and Tideglusib, a GSK-3β inhibitor partially rescued the PC12 cells from the AS-induced cytotoxicity and restored the expression of NFATc3. In addition, overexpression of NFATc3 stimulated neurite outgrowth and potentiated the effect of NGF on promoting the neurite outgrowth. Collectively, our results show that NFATc3 serves as the downstream target of NGF and plays a key role in preventing AS-induced neurotoxicity through regulating the AKT/GSK-3β/NFAT pathway in PC12 cells. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: arsenic sulfide; glycogen synthase kinase-3 beta (GSK-3β); nerve growth factor (NGF); nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT); PC12

Authors: Ham J., Kim J., Bazer F.W., Lim W., Song G.
Title: Silibinin-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress and mitochondrial dysfunction suppress growth of endometriotic lesions
Affiliations: Department of Biotechnology, Institute of Animal Molecular Biotechnology, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Department of Animal Science, Center for Animal Biotechnology and Genomics, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States; Department of Biomedical Sciences, Catholic Kwandong University, Gangneung, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ham, J., Department of Biotechnology, Institute of Animal Molecular Biotechnology, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, J., Department of Biotechnology, Institute of Animal Molecular Biotechnology, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Bazer, F.W., Department of Animal Science, Center for Animal Biotechnology and Genomics, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States; Lim, W., Department of Biomedical Sciences, Catholic Kwandong University, Gangneung, South Korea; Song, G., Department of Biotechnology, Institute of Animal Molecular Biotechnology, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Silibinin is a flavonolignan extracted from milk thistle, which has been used for treating liver disorders, various cancers, and gynecological diseases. However, attempts for treating endometriosis with silibinin are lacking. In this study, we observed that silibinin exerts antiproliferative and apoptotic effects on human endometriotic cell lines VK2/E6E7 and End1/E6E7. We also identified that silibinin-induced oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation in human endometriotic cells. Moreover, we observed upregulation of calcium concentration in the cytosol and mitochondrial matrix, which resulted in mitochondrial dysfunction. Furthermore, induction of endoplasmic reticulum stress signals with rapid mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway signaling resulted in apoptosis of both cells. Using an animal model mimicking the retrograde menstruation hypothesis, we verified the effects of silibinin on reducing endometriotic lesions by inhibiting the expression of inflammatory cytokines in mice. Silibinin might be used as a novel therapeutic agent or supplement for inhibiting progression of endometriosis in vitro and in vivo. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: apoptosis; endometriosis; endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress; ROS; silibinin

Authors: Crhák T., Zachová D., Fojtová M., Sýkorová E.
Title: The region upstream of the telomerase reverse transcriptase gene is essential for in planta telomerase complementation
Affiliations: The Czech Academy of Sciences, Institute of Biophysics, Brno, Czech Republic; Mendel Centre for Plant Genomics and Proteomics, Central European Institute of Technology (CEITEC), Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Crhák, T., The Czech Academy of Sciences, Institute of Biophysics, Brno, Czech Republic, Mendel Centre for Plant Genomics and Proteomics, Central European Institute of Technology (CEITEC), Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Zachová, D., Mendel Centre for Plant Genomics and Proteomics, Central European Institute of Technology (CEITEC), Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Fojtová, M., Mendel Centre for Plant Genomics and Proteomics, Central European Institute of Technology (CEITEC), Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Sýkorová, E., The Czech Academy of Sciences, Institute of Biophysics, Brno, Czech Republic
Abstract: Telomerase is essential for the maintenance of telomeres, structures located at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes that are crucial for genomic stability. Telomerase has been frequently explored in mammals because of its activity in many types of cancers, but knowledge in plants is rather sketchy despite plants representing useful models due to peculiarities in their telomeres and telomerase biology. We studied in planta complementation of telomerase in Arabidopsis thaliana mutant plants with disrupted expression of the gene encoding the telomerase protein subunit (AtTERT) and significantly shortened telomeres. We found that the upstream region of AtTERT, previously identified as a putative minimal promoter, was essential for reconstitution of telomerase function, as demonstrated by the full or partial recovery of the telomere phenotype in mutants. In contrast, transformation by the full length AtTERT gene construct resulted in more progressive telomere shortening in mutants and even in wild type plants, despite the high level of AtTERT transcript and telomerase activity detected by in vitro assay. Thus, the telomerase protein subunit putative promoter is essential for in planta telomerase reconstitution and restoration of its catalytical activity. Contributions from other factors, including those tissue-specific, for proper telomerase function are discussed. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Arabidopsis thaliana; Complementation; in planta; Promoter; Telomerase; Telomere

Authors: Lv D., Gu Y., Guo M., Hou P., Li Y., Wu R.
Title: Perfluorooctanoic acid exposure induces apoptosis in SMMC-7721 hepatocellular cancer cells
Affiliations: School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; School of Science, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China
Authors with affiliations: Lv, D., School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; Gu, Y., School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; Guo, M., School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China, School of Science, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; Hou, P., School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; Li, Y., School of Forestry and Bio-technology, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China; Wu, R., School of Science, Zhejiang Agricultural & Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang  311300, China
Abstract: The cytotoxicity (SMMC-7721) of PFOA was measured. The amount-effect relationship of the PFOA toxicity was elucidated at the cellular and molecular level. © 2019 Elsevier LtdTo better understand the toxicological activities of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), we examined the effects of PFOA on apoptosis and its molecular mechanism in SMMC-7721 hepatoma cells. Cell viability was evaluated by MTT assay and apoptosis was determined by flow cytometry. Western blot and quantitative real-time PCR were used to examine the protein and gene expressions of Bax and Bcl-2. Our results showed that PFOA inhibited SMMC-7721 cell growth and induced apoptosis. PFOA treatment increased Bax expression and increased Bcl-2 expression at both gene and protein levels. Our study demonstrated that PFOA had toxic effects on SMMC-7721 cells, such as inhibiting cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis. Furthermore, we showed that PFOA-mediated induction of apoptosis involved inducing Bax and decreasing Bcl-2 expression as a molecular mechanism of its toxicological effects. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd
Author Keywords: Apoptosis; Bcl gene family; Ecology-toxicological effect; Perfluorooctanoic acid; SMMC-7721 cells

Authors: Chen W., Huang Y., Zhang S., Zheng X., Xie S., Mao J., Cai Y., Lu X., Hu L., Shen J., Dong Y., Chai K.
Title: MicroRNA-212 suppresses nonsmall lung cancer invasion and migration by regulating ubiquitin-specific protease-9
Affiliations: Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Department of pharmacy, The Affiliated Cangnan Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University, The People’s Hospital of Cangnan, Wenzhou, China; Department of Oncology, The Second Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University School of Medicine, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, W., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Huang, Y., Department of pharmacy, The Affiliated Cangnan Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University, The People’s Hospital of Cangnan, Wenzhou, China; Zhang, S., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Zheng, X., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Xie, S., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Lu, X., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Hu, L., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Shen, J., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China; Dong, Y., Department of Oncology, The Second Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University School of Medicine, Hangzhou, China; Chai, K., Cancer Institute of Integrated Taditional Chinese and Western Medicine, Zhejiang Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tongde Hospital of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play crucial roles in various biological processes, including migration, proliferation, differentiation, cell cycling, and apoptosis. Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) has been shown to be related to the capability of migration and invasion in many tumor cells. In this study, we used wound-healing assay and transwell invasion to analysis the capability of migration and invasion in non–small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), respectively. The expression of ubiquitin-specific protease-9-X-linked (USP9X) and miR-212 messenger RNA (mRNA) was determined by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction and Western blot analysis was used to determine the E-cadherin and vimentin expression. Our results showed that miR-212 mimic inhibited cell migration and invasion, while miR-212 inhibitor increased cell migration and invasion. There was no significant difference between WP1130 and miR-212 mimic combined with WP1130 groups. Moreover, WP1130 inhibited the capability of the migration and invasion of NSCLC cells. Western blot analysis displayed that miR-212 mimic upregulated E-cadherin expression and downregulated vimentin expression, while miR-212 inhibitor downregulated E-cadherin and upregulated vimentin expression. These data showed that miR-212 regulated NSCLC cell invasion and migration by regulating USP9X expression. Taken together, these findings indicated that miR-212 regulated NSCLC cells migration and invasion through targeting USP9X involved in EMT. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: epithelial-mesenchymal transition; invasion and migration; microRNA; non–small-cell lung carcinoma; therapeutic; ubiquitin-specific protease-9-X-linked

Title: TIPE3 is a regulator of cell apoptosis in glioblastoma

Chen, Q., Department of Neurosurgery, Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University, Wuhan, Hubei  430060, China, Central Laboratory, Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University, Wuhan, Hubei  430060, China
Abstract: Tumor necrosis factor alpha-induced protein 8-like 3 (TIPE3) is closely related to tumourigenesis and development. However, its role in human glioblastoma (GBM) and the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. In this study, we demonstrate that TIPE3 is upregulated in GBM, and its high expression predicts poor prognosis. TIPE3 depletion induces GBM cell apoptosis both in vitro and in vivo. Mechanism studies reveal that TIPE3 inhibits p38 phosphorylation and negatively regulates the p38 MAPK pathway. TIPE3 associates with p38. The nuclear translocation of p38 is blocked by TIPE3 overexpression. And p38 phosphorylation could regulate TIPE3-mediated p38 nuclear-cytopalsmic translocation but does not affect TIPE3-p38 association. Rescue experiments confirm that TIPE3 inhibits GBM cell apoptosis via the p38 MAPK pathway. In conclusion, TIPE3 inhibits p38 phosphorylation and blocks p38 nuclear translocation. This action thus negatively regulates the p38 MAPK pathway and results in GBM cell survival. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.

Authors: Arroyo V.M., Lupo P.J., Scheurer M.E., Rednam S.P., Murray J., Okcu M.F., Chintagumpala M.M., Brown A.L.
Title: Pilot study of DNA methylation-derived neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio and survival in pediatric medulloblastoma
Affiliations: Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States; Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Cook Children's Medical Center, Ft. Worth, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arroyo, V.M., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States; Lupo, P.J., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Scheurer, M.E., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Rednam, S.P., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Murray, J., Cook Children's Medical Center, Ft. Worth, TX, United States; Okcu, M.F., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Chintagumpala, M.M., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States; Brown, A.L., Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX, United States, Texas Children's Cancer and Hematology Centers, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: Introduction: Methylation-derived neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (mdNLR) has been identified as a potential prognostic biomarker of outcomes in various cancers. We evaluated the prognostic value of blood-derived mdNLR within a retrospective cohort of pediatric medulloblastoma patients. Materials and methods: DNA methylation was measured in archival peripheral blood samples collected on 56 pediatric medulloblastoma patients. Hazard ratios (HR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for the association between mdNLR and survival were evaluated using Cox proportional hazard models. Results: Compared to patients who were alive at last follow-up (n = 43), the mean mdNLR value was slightly higher in deceased patients (n = 13) (12.3 vs. 5.2,P = 0.163). Elevated log-transformed mdNLR was suggestively associated with an increased likelihood of death in unadjusted models (HR=1.43, 95%CI: 0.92–2.22) and significantly associated with mortality in adjusted models (HR=1.61, 95%CI: 1.01–2.58). Discussion: Future work is warranted to investigate the relationship between mdNLR outcomes in specific pediatric medulloblastoma molecular subgroups. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd

Authors: Yao B.-R., Sun Y., Chen S.-L., Suo H.-D., Zhang Y.-L., Wei H., Wang C.-H., Zhao F., Cong W., Xin W.-Y., Hou G.-G.
Title: Dissymmetric pyridyl-substituted 3,5-bis(arylidene)-4-piperidones as anti-hepatoma agents by inhibiting NF-κB pathway activation
Affiliations: School of Pharmacy, The Key Laboratory of Prescription Effect and Clinical Evaluation of State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine of China, Binzhou Medical University, Yantai, 264003, China
Authors with affiliations: Yao, B.-R., School of Pharmacy, The Key Laboratory of Prescription Effect and Clinical Evaluation of State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine of China, Binzhou Medical University, Yantai, 264003, China; Hou, G.-G., School of Pharmacy, The Key Laboratory of Prescription Effect and Clinical Evaluation of State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine of China, Binzhou Medical University, Yantai, 264003, China
Abstract: To get new anti-hepatoma agents with anti-inflammatory activity and hypotoxicity, a series of dissymmetric pyridyl-substituted 3,5-bis(arylidene)-4-piperidones (BAPs, 25–82) were designed and synthesized. Many of them exhibited potential anti-hepatoma properties against human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines (HepG2, QGY-7703, SMMC-7721) and hypotoxicity for human normal heptical cell line (HHL-5, LO2), and prominently inhibited lipopolysaccharides (LPS) induced IL-6, TNF-α secretion to exert its anti-inflammatory effect. Combining the data of cytotoxicity, cytocompatibility and anti-inflammatory activity, 3-pyridyl and -CF 3 substituted 67 may be the potential anti-hepatoma agent. 67 effectively promoted cell apoptosis through up-regulating cleaved caspase-3 and Bax expression and down-regulating Bcl-2 expression. Furthermore, 67 prominently inhibited NF-κB pathway activation by blocking the phosphorylation of IκBα p65 and the nuclear translocation of NF-κB induced by TNF-α and LPS. In addition, 67 could reasonably bind to the active site of Bcl-2 and NF-κB/p65 protein proved by Molecular docking analyses. Moreover, 67 significantly suppressed the growth and inflammatory response of HepG2 xenografts in nude mice and was relatively nontoxic to mice. These results suggest that 67 may be effective and hypotoxicity anti-hepatoma agent for the clinical treatment of liver cancers. © 2019 Elsevier Masson SAS
Author Keywords: 3,5-Bis(arylidene)-4-piperidones; Anti-hepatoma agents; Anti-inflammatory; Cytotoxicity; Molecular docking; Tumor xenograft

Authors: Wei G., Liang T., Wei C., Nong X., Lu Q., Zhao J.
Title: Daidzin inhibits RANKL-induced osteoclastogenesis in vitro and prevents LPS-induced bone loss in vivo
Affiliations: Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China; Department of Orthopedics, No.303 hospital of PLAGuangxi, China; Department of Orthopedics, Affiliated Hospital of Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Wei, G., Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China, Department of Orthopedics, No.303 hospital of PLAGuangxi, China; Liang, T., Department of Orthopedics, Affiliated Hospital of Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, China; Wei, C., Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China; Nong, X., Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China; Lu, Q., Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China; Zhao, J., Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station, Guangxi Medical UniversityGuangxi, China
Abstract: Osteoclasts are multinuclear giant cells responsible for bone resorption in bone loss diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, periodontitis, and the aseptic loosening of orthopedic implants. Because of injurious side effects with currently available drugs, it is necessary to continue research novel bone-protective therapies. Daidzin, a naturally occurring isoflavone found in leguminous plants, has numerous beneficial pharmacologic effects, including anti-cancer, anti-cholesterol, and anti-angiocardiopathy, promoting osteoblasts differentiation, and even anti-osteoporosis. However, the effect of daidzin on the regulation of osteoclast activity has not yet been investigated. In this study, our study showed that daidzin significantly inhibited receptor activator of nuclear factor-kB ligand (RANKL)-induced osteoclast differentiation of bone marrow macrophages and the hydroxyapatite-resorbing activity of mature osteoclasts by inhibiting RANKL-induced NF-kB signaling pathway. In addition, daidzin could inhibit the expression of osteoclast marker genes, including nuclear factor of activated T cells cytoplasmic 1 (NFATc1), cellular oncogene fos (c-Fos), tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), and cathepsin K (CTSK). Consistent with in vitro results, daidzin inhibited lipopolysaccharide-induced bone loss by suppressing the osteoclast differentiation. Together our data demonstrated that daidzin inhibits RANKL-induced osteoclastogenesis through suppressing NF-ĸB signaling pathway and that daidzin is a promising agent in the treatment of osteolytic diseases. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: daidzin; osteoclast; osteoclastogenesis; osteolytic diseases
Funding Text 1: This study was supported by Guangxi Medical University Postdoctoral Research Station (02305217038X, 02306217008D).

Title: Identification of novel biomarkers for hepatocellular carcinoma using transcriptome analysis

Authors with affiliations: Xia, Q., Scientific Research Center, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China; Li, Z., Department of General Surgery, Zhong Shan Hospital, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Zheng, J., Department of Laboratory Medicine, Zhoupu Hospital Affiliated to Shanghai University of Medicine & Health Sciences, Shanghai, China; Zhang, X., National Center for Liver Cancer, Shanghai, China; Di, Y., Department of Pancreatic Surgery, Pancreatic Disease Institute, Huashan Hospital, Shanghai Medical College, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Ding, J., Eastern Hepatobiliary Surgery Hospital, The Second Military Medical University, Shanghai, China; Yu, D., Scientific Research Center, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China; Yan, L., Department of Severe Hepatology, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China; Shen, L., Scientific Research Center, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China; Yan, D., Department of Medical Oncology, Beijing Chaoyang Hospital Affiliated to Capital Medical University, Beijing, China; Jia, N., Scientific Research Center, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China, Laboratory of Molecular Biology and Department of Biochemistry, Anhui Medical University, Hefei, Anhui, China; Chen, W., Microarray Core, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, United States; Feng, Y., Department of Pathology, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China; Wang, J., Scientific Research Center, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, Fudan University, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the third leading cause of death from cancer in the world. To comprehensively investigate the utility of microRNAs (miRNAs) and protein-encoding transcripts (messenger RNAs [mRNAs]) in HCC as potential biomarkers for early detection and diagnosis, we exhaustively mined genomic data from three available omics datasets (GEO, Oncomine, and TCGA), analyzed the overlaps among gene expression studies from 920 hepatocellular carcinoma samples and 508 healthy (or adjacent normal) liver tissue samples available from six laboratories, and identified 178 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) associated with HCC. Paired with miRNA and lncRNA data, we identified 23 core genes that were targeted by nine differentially expressed miRNAs and 21 HCC-specific lncRNAs. We further demonstrated that alterations in these 23 genes were quite frequent, with five genes altered in over 5% of the population. Patients with high levels of YWHAZ, ENAH, and HMGN4 tended to have high-grade tumors and shorter overall survival, suggesting that these genes could be promising candidate biomarkers for disease and poor prognosis in patients Swith HCC. Our comprehensive mRNA, miRNA, and lncRNA omics analyses from multiple independent datasets identified robust molecules that may be used as biomarkers for early HCC detection and diagnosis. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: biomarkers; HCC; lncRNAs; miRNAs; network analysis; transcriptomic analysis

Authors: Liu Q., Xu X., Zeng J., Shi X., Liao Y., Du P., Tang Y., Huang W., Chen Q., Shou L.
Title: Heavy metal concentrations in commercial marine organisms from Xiangshan Bay, China, and the potential health risks
Affiliations: Second Institute of Oceanography, Ministry of Natural Resources, Hangzhou, 310012, China; Key Laboratory of Marine Ecosystem and Biogeochemistry, State Oceanic Administration, Hangzhou, 310012, China; Ocean College of Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, 316000, China

Abstract: Commercial marine organisms were collected from the coast of Xiangshan Bay to investigate the concentrations of eight heavy metals (As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Hg, Ni, Pb, and Zn) and evaluate the potential health risks. The results indicated considerable variations in the heavy metal concentrations among six species groups, of them mollusks (seasnail, benthic bivalve, and oyster) generally contained relative high levels of most metals, followed by crustaceans (crab and shrimp), by contrast, fish had low concentrations of all metals, except Hg. Three heavy metal groups were identified to interpret the accumulative characteristics in the marine organisms. Spatial distributions illustrated the geographical variations of heavy metal concentrations in the sampling areas. Moreover, maricultured organisms demonstrated lower heavy metal concentrations than did the wild. Health risks of most heavy metals exposed from marine organism consumption were safe, except for As which is associated with the high target cancer risk values. © 2019
Author Keywords: Crustacean; Fish; Health risk; Heavy metal; Mollusk; Xiangshan Bay
Funding Text 1: Heavy metal Mollusk Crustacean Fish Health risk Xiangshan Bay The coastal environment of China has been heavily contaminated by the terrestrial pollutants which released from land-based sources through rivers and land runoff with the rapid urbanization and industrialization over the last few decades ( Pan and Wang, 2012 ; M. Wang et al., 2018 ). Heavy metals represent a major category of these pollutants of great concern for marine organisms and the consumers because of their potential toxicity, persistence, and bioaccumulation ( Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ; La Colla et al., 2018 ). State Oceanic Administration (SOA) of China reported that the total amount of Zn, Cu, Pb, Cd, Hg, and As influx from the Yangtze River to the East China Sea in 2017 was estimated to be 13,160 tons, which was considerably higher than that from other rivers in China ( SOA, 2018 ). Therefore, more attention should be focused on heavy metal pollution in the coastal environment of East China Sea ( Huang et al., 2007 ). Heavy metals in water, suspended particulate matter, and sediment of the coastal environment can be taken up and accumulated by marine organisms ( Jordao et al., 2002 ). The heavy metal concentrations in the tissues of different marine organism species heavily varied not only from their physiological and metabolizable processes, but also from their living environment ( Sunlu, 2006 ; Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ; Baki et al., 2018 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). Therefore, some marine organisms are excellent indicators for long-term monitoring of heavy metal contamination levels in various marine environments ( Baki et al., 2018 ). For example, bivalve mollusks, particularly oyster, mussels, and clams, have been used to monitor heavy metal pollution in marine water and sediment of coastal areas ( Zhou et al., 2008 ; J. Liu et al., 2017 ). Crabs, a typical benthic organism, can be considered as an excellent indicator for measuring heavy metal contamination in the surface sediment ( Ololade et al., 2011 ). Fish can be used as excellent biomonitor to estimate heavy metal levels in water ( Zhou et al., 2008 ). Heavy metal accumulation in the marine organisms can cause severe damage and toxic effects to animals, which may further lead to high ecological risk ( Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ; Gu et al., 2017 ). In addition, heavy metals in the tissues of marine organisms may transfer to humans through seafood consumption, which is increasing rapidly due to the beneficial nutrition ( Guérin et al., 2011 ). Marine mollusks, crustaceans, and fish usually contain essential amino acids for humans, and they are crucial sources of minerals, vitamins, and polyunsaturated fatty acids ( Fuentes et al., 2009 ). Therefore, increasing seafood consumption can result in potential health risks for humans, particularly the coastal residents who rely on seafood as their primary source of animal protein ( Chien et al., 2002 ; Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). The Xiangshan Bay, one of the most important semi-enclosed mariculture bases, is located on the coast of the East China Sea, with a length of 60 km, width of approximately 10 km at the mouth, shallow depth of <10 m at the bay head, and deep depth of 20–30 m in the middle segment ( Sun et al., 2014 ; Yang et al., 2018 ). Its water is sourced mainly from the coastal waters, including the Changjiang Diluted Water, which is the large amount of fresh water discharged from Yangtze River (also known as Changjiang River) spreading over the East China Sea continental shelf as low salinity water ( Matsuno et al., 2006 ; Zhu et al., 2017 ; Yang et al., 2018 ). More than 50,000 tons of mollusks, shrimp, crabs, and fish are produced for consumption in Xiangshan Bay every year ( Huang et al., 2008 ). However, the levels of heavy metals in the environment of the bay are influenced by anthropogenic inputs, with high enrichment of some metals in the sediment because of wastewater discharge and low energy hydrodynamic environment ( Sun et al., 2014 ). Therefore, heavy metal concentrations in the marine organisms collected from Xiangshan Bay can not only indicate heavy metal contamination, but also aid in evaluating the potential health risk of seafood consumption. In the present study, we determined the concentrations of eight heavy metals namely As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Hg, Ni, Pb, and Zn in the commercial species of mollusks, crustaceans, and fish collected from the coast of Xiangshan Bay to achieve the following objectives: 1) investigate concentrations of heavy metals in marine organisms collected from the Xiangshan Bay and compare the variations among different species, 2) examine the geographic variation of heavy metals levels in the Xiangshan Bay used by the bioindicators of marine organisms, 3) compare the heavy metal concentrations between maricultured and wild organisms, and 4) evaluate the potential health risk of heavy metals for local residents by calculating the daily intake and target hazard quotient (THQ) resulting from seafood consumption. Three commercial mollusk groups, namely seasnail, including spotted babylon ( ) in April 2016. The approximate average body length for each species were 3, 2, 3, 5, 2.5, 2, 2.5, and 4 cm and weight were 10, 5, 10, 18, 8, 6, 8, and 12 g, respectively. Crustaceans comprised crab, including intertidal ocypodid crab ( Babylonia areolata ), Korean mud snail ( Bullacta exarata ), and dog whelk ( Thais clavigera ), benthic bivalve including razor clam ( Sinonovacula constricta ), short necked clam ( Ruditapes philippinarum ), subcrenated ark ( Scapharca subcrenata ), and blood clam ( Tegillarca granosa ), and giant Pacific oyster ( Ostrea cucullata ) were collected from sampling sites 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 12, 15, and 16 in the coastal areas of Xiangshan Bay ( Fig. 1 Macrophthalmus japonicus ), fiddler crab ( Ocypoda stimpsoni ), swimming crab ( Portunus trituberculatus ), and mangrove crab ( Scylla serrata ), and shrimp, including whiteleg shrimp ( Penaeus vannamei ), Chinese white shrimp ( Fenneropenaeus chinensis ), and mantis shrimp ( Oratosquilla oratoria ), were collected from sampling sites 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, and 14 ( Fig. 1 ) in April 2016. The approximate average body length for each species were 4, 4, 8, 6, 12, 10, and 10 cm and weight were 20, 25, 100, 80, 30, 20, and 18 g, respectively. Samples of consumed fish, including bigmouth grenadier anchovy ( Coilia macrognathos ), soles ( Cynoglossus abbreviatus ), long-finned herring ( Ilisha elongata ), large yellow croaker ( Larimichthys crocea ), flathead gray mullet ( Mugil cephalus ), Japanese sea perch ( Perca fluviatilis ), mudskipper ( Periophthalmus modestus ), and Japanese Spanish mackerel ( Scomberomorus niphonius ), were collected from sites 6, 7, 10, 11, 13, 14, and 16 ( Fig. 1 ) in April 2016, with the approximate average body length for each species of 20, 25, 20, 30, 25, 35, 8, and 20 cm and weight of 120, 300, 200, 400, 300, 500, 20, and 250 g, respectively. Mollusk samples were collected by local fishermen from the clearly defined coastal sites of Xiangshan Bay. Wild crustacean and fish samples were collected through bottom trawling of our research cruise, and the cultured samples were obtained from the farmers at mariculture zones. Immediately after collection, the living marine organism samples were washed with seawater, placed in pre-cleaned polyethylene bags and, thereafter, transported to the laboratory in an icebox. After transportation, the samples were rinsed with deionized water to remove surface adherents. The edible portions of the collected organism samples were dissected with clean stainless steel knives. Tissues of 15 individuals for each mollusk and crustacean species and five individuals for each fish species collected from the same sampling site or same mariculture zone were homogenized as a single mixed sample in a blender. The mixed wet samples were frozen at −20 °C immediately after accurately weighing and then freeze-dried with a vacuum freeze dryer (Christ Delta 1-24LS, Germany). The dried tissue samples were weighed to calculate the ratio of moisture content for use in health risk assessment and then ground into powder by using an agate mortar. The powder samples were stored at −20 °C until further analysis. Approximately 0.2 ± 0.005 g freeze-dried samples of marine organism tissues were weighed into Teflon digestion vessels and digested using 10 mL HNO 3 (ultra pure, Merck, Germany) in a microwave system (CEM Mars 6, USA) with the previously described conditions ( Liu et al., 2015 ). After digestion, the solution was diluted to 25 mL with ultra pure water (18.2 MΩ cm −2 Milli-Q water, Millipore) for heavy metal analysis. The concentrations of seven metals (As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Ni, Pb, and Zn) were determined using an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS, PerkinElmer, Elan DRC-e, USA). The Hg concentration was evaluated through atomic fluorescence spectrometry (Skyray Instrument, AFS200, China). The concentrations of studied heavy metals are expressed as μg/g dry weight (dw). The detection limits of the methodology calculated using triple standard deviation values of blanks and average dry weight of samples were As (0.005 μg/g), Cd (<0.001 μg/g), Cr (0.018 μg/g), Cu (0.025 μg/g), Ni (0.002 μg/g), Pb (0.005 μg/g), Zn (0.008 μg/g), and Hg (0.003 μg/g), respectively. Standard reference material (CRM shrimp, GBW10050) from the Center of National Standard Reference Material of China was used to verify accuracy of the analysis by using the same procedures as that for the samples. The recovery rates for standard reference materials were within 10% of the certified values. One-half value of the limit of detection was assigned in the case of undetected concentrations. The one-sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov (K S) test was used to assess the data normality. All the concentration values for eight heavy metals in the tissues of six marine species groups (seasnail, benthic bivalve, oyster, crab, shrimp, and fish) were normally distributed at the 95% confidence level. Therefore, the variations of heavy metal concentrations in the six groups were assessed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), and the significance was determined at p  < 0.05. Principal components analysis (PCA) was used to explore the associations among heavy metals in the tissues of marine organisms. All statistical analyses in this study were performed using the statistical package SPSS 20.0 (IBM SPSS Statistics, IBM Corp., USA). The concentrations of eight heavy metals in mollusks (seasnail, benthic bivalve, and oyster), crustaceans (crab and shrimp), and fish collected from 16 sampling sites in Xiangshan Bay were compared based on the statistical analysis of one-way ANOVA ( ). Overall, according to the results, the concentrations of all selected heavy metals except for As ( Fig. 2 F 5, 36  = 2.436, p  = 0.053) varied significantly among the six groups of different marine species ( F 5, 36  ≥ 3.524, p  ≤ 0.011). The ranking order of the mean concentration for eight metals in all the marine organisms from Xiangshan Bay (n = 42) was Zn > Cu > As > Cr > Cd > Ni > Pb > Hg, with a trend similar to that in the previous studies ( Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). This result indicated the variation in the accumulation of different heavy metals in marine organism tissues. Marine organisms can readily assimilate and considerably accumulate the freely dissolved and transported heavy metals in seawater ( Jordao et al., 2002 ). The variation in heavy metal concentrations among different marine species was mainly because of several factors, such as the feeding strategies, metabolic abilities, physiological activities, living habits, migration, and heavy metal affinity for specific organs of marine organisms ( J. Liu et al., 2017 ; Baki et al., 2018 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). In general, in this study, mollusks including seasnail, benthic bivalve, and oyster contained relative high levels of most metals, including Cd, Cr, Cu, Ni, Pb, and Zn, especially Cd, Cu, Ni, and Pb ( Fig. 2 ). The highest concentrations of Cd (13.27 μg/g dw), Cu (719.48 μg/g dw), Hg (0.16 μg/g dw), Ni (3.66 μg/g dw), Pb (1.79 μg/g dw), and Zn (1976.86 μg/g dw) for six groups of marine organisms were discovered in oyster tissues, of which Cd and Cu exhibited significant variations ( p  < 0.05). Oysters accumulate high concentrations of heavy metals through filter feeding from surrounding seawater with extremely high metal accumulation factors for Cu and Zn. The related studies that attempted to address how oysters tolerate such high Cu and Zn levels in their tissues indicated that: 1) compartmentalization of toxic metals in the membrane-limited vesicles of hemocytes played an important detoxificatory role for the oysters ( Weng and Wang, 2015 ) and 2) oysters may efficiently detoxify the excessive Cu and Zn by storing them in oxygen- and nitrogen-bonded complexes ( Tan et al., 2015 ). Moreover, previous studies demonstrated that Cu or Zn accumulation in oysters facilitated other toxic metals absorption, such as Cd and Hg ( Liu and Wang, 2013, 2014 ). Such metal interactions may partly explain the high concentrations of Cd, Hg, Ni, and Pb in the oysters. Furthermore, seasnail exhibited high levels of all heavy metals, with the highest concentration of As (35.62 μg/g dw) in the soft tissue among the six groups and highest concentration of Cr (7.62 μg/g dw) in the mollusk species ( Fig. 2 ). Seasnail is a predatory carnivorous or omnivorous species and mainly feeds on bivalves and other marine organisms ( Liu et al., 2018 ; Zhelyazkov et al., 2018 ). Aquatic biota may accumulate heavy metals through trophic transfer. Therefore, because of these special food chains, the heavy metal concentraitons in seasnails were generally higher than bivalves as described in previous studies ( Topcuoglu et al., 2002 ; Zhelyazkov et al., 2018 ). In addition, this mollusk species has often been used as an environmental pollution biomonitor because it contains high metal levels in their soft tissues ( Mulayim and Balkıs, 2015 ; Zhelyazkov et al., 2018 ). Compared with other two mollusk groups, benthic bivalve contained the lowest levels of the eight metals, but the concentrations of Cd (0.45 μg/g dw), Ni (1.23 μg/g dw), and Pb (0.58 μg/g dw) in benthic bivalve tissues were slightly higher than those in crustaceans and fish ( Fig. 2 ). In contrast with oyster, which is a sessile species living on the surface of reefs or rocks and mainly feeds on suspended materials, benthic bivalves generally inhabit sediments and primarily feed on organic detritus, benthic diatoms, and zoobenthos ( J. Liu et al., 2017 ). Benthic bivalves typically tend to accumulate more heavy metals than do sessile species because of the high enrichment of heavy metals in sediments ( L.Q. Zhao et al., 2012 ). However, their metal concentrations were comparatively low in this study because of the special heavy metal accumulation mechanism in oysters and food chain enrichment in seasnails, which agreed with reported reviews ( Wang and Lu, 2017 ). As examined in previous studies, benthic bivalves ( e.g. , clams) displayed a relatively high dietary assimilation and elimination, which indicated that the fast efflux of heavy metals might be a crucial mechanism for the metal regulation in benthic bivalves; thus maintaining a low heavy metal concentration in the tissue when compared with oysters and seasnails ( Pan and Wang, 2009 ). Crustaceans ( e.g. , crab and shrimp) are typical benthic organisms. Thus, they could heavily accumulate some essential and toxic trace metals by their particular physiological, biochemical strategies, and living habits ( Baki et al., 2018 ). The hepatopancreas of crab and other crustaceans accumulate high amounts of heavy metals and played a crucial role in metal detoxification ( Wang et al., 2001 ; Reinecke et al., 2003 ). Moreover, crab and shrimp are mobile benthic species and reside above the sediment, which results in more heavy metal accumulation from the sediment ( S. Zhao et al., 2012 ). In this study, the concentrations of As detected in the crab and shrimp samples (28.42 and 33.48 μg/g dw, respectively) were considerably higher than that in the benthic bivalve, oyster, and fish samples ( Fig. 2 ). The Cr concentration (8.26 μg/g dw) in shrimp was much higher than benthic bivalves, oyster, crabs, and fish, but was comparable with that in seasnails ( Fig. 2 ). Among the species of crustacean, high concentration of Cr was observed in shrimp. However, toxic Hg concentration in crab samples (0.13 μg/g dw) was considerably higher than that in shrimp. Moreover, the Zn concentration in the crab (215.34 μg/g dw) was comparatively higher than that in shrimp (61.84 μg/g dw), and other metal concentrations did not exhibit obvious difference between the crustacean species. These results indicated that the close taxa species in the same genus accumulated different concentrations of several metals as described in previous studies ( Baki et al., 2018 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). In addition, crustaceans were considered excellent biomarkers for measuring heavy metal contamination in surface sediments ( Baki et al., 2018 ). Based on the results of this study, heavy metal concentrations in fish muscles exhibited considerably lower concentrations than that of other marine organism groups, except for Hg. The mean concentration of Hg in fish muscle was 0.10 μg/g dw, which was comparable with that in seasnail, oyster, and crab, but considerably higher than that in bivalves and shrimp ( ). A review study indicated that muscle MeHg concentrations as low as 0.2–0.5 μg/g ww in teleost fish might influence the biochemical processes and reduce reproductions ( Fig. 2 ). Fish mainly assimilate metals from surrounding seawater through three ways including ingestion from suspended particulate materials, ion exchange across lipophilic membranes during breathing, and food chain delivery from their diet ( Yi et al., 2011 ). Thus, fish can be used as bioindicators of metal contamination in aquatic environment ( Gu et al., 2017 ) and the assimilation mechanisms result in lower levels of metal concentration than that in mollusk and crustacean ( Liu et al., 2018 ). However, it has been established that fish usually accumulate more Hg with concentrations of >0.5 μg/g dw in the fish from other coastal areas, which was mainly due to their high trophic levels ( García-Hernández et al., 2018 ). The average concentration of Hg in fish muscle tissues was 0.023 μg/g wet weight (ww) with a range from 0.004 to 0.083 μg/g ww ( Tables 1 and 2 Depew et al., 2012 ). Moreover, the maximum permissible level for Hg recommended by the World Health Organization and The National Health and Family Planning of People's Republic of China (NFHPC) is 0.5 μg/g ww ( WHO, 1990 ; NFHPC, 2017 ). WHO recommends a lower guideline of 0.2 μg/g ww for Hg to protect vulnerable people, including pregnant women, children under 15 years old, and those who consume fish frequently ( WHO, 1990 ). The concentrations of Hg in the fish muscles in this study were considerably lower than the risk or maximum permissible level. However, most of the Hg (>80%) in the muscle tissues of various fish species was methylmercury (MeHg), the most toxic and bioaccumulative form of Hg in marine ecosystems ( Matulik et al., 2017 ; Zhang et al., 2018 ). Table 1 compares heavy metal concentrations expressed on the basis of wet weight in seasnail, benthic bivalve, oyster, crab, shrimp, and fish of this study with the reported concentrations in marine organisms collected from other areas. In general, most heavy metal concentrations in marine organisms collected from Xiangshan Bay were comparable to those from other areas. The Cu concentrations in the benthic bivalve and oyster in this study were slightly higher than those in others, but Cd and Cu concentrations in the fish were much lower than those in others areas. Moreover, Ni and Pb concentrations in the marine organisms were lower than the concentrations in other areas. The As and Zn concentrations in the marine organisms varied heavily depending on different species and study areas. The concentrations of different heavy metals in the marine organisms varied heavily because of many complex factors, such as environmental parameters ( ). Before PCA, Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin (KMO) measure of sampling adequacy and Bartlett's test of sphericity were used to examine the validity of PCA, with provided results of 0.661 and 293.5 (df = 28, e.g. , pH, temperature, salinity, content of cation exchange capacity, and heavy metal concentrations in seawater or sediment), physiological factors ( e.g. , tissues, organs, and feeding conditions for organisms), and physicochemical properties and biological activities or toxicities of metal ions ( Sunlu, 2006 ; Chen et al., 2015 ; Liu et al., 2018 ). In this study, PCA was used to visually exhibit the associations among the analyzed metals in all the marine organisms. The result is presented as the rotated component loading plot ( Fig. 3 p  < 0.01), respectively. This indicated that PCA was useful in dimensionality reduction ( Gu et al., 2012 ). The first three principal components of the PCA explained 80.64% of the total variance in this study. The first principal component, which accounted for 38.20% of the total variance, was mainly dominated by Cu, Zn, Cd, and Hg with the loading of 91.1%, 92.4%, 89.7%, and 63.6%, respectively. The second component explained 24.0% of the total variance and was dominated by Ni and Pb with the loading of 84.3% and 85.0%, respectively. The third component that was dominated by Cr (87.9%) and As (82.9%) explained 18.45% of the total variance. According to the PCA methodology, the relationships between the three components were relatively independent. However, metal relationships were close within each component. Therefore, three independent heavy metal groups were identified in this study, which indicated different accumulative characteristics among the metal groups in the marine organisms tissues. However, similar accumulative characteristics occurred within the metal groups ( Liu et al., 2018 ). The geographical variation in heavy metal concentrations in marine organisms was commonly related to the local pollution status ( , respectively, to illustrate their geographical variation or contamination in Xiangshan Bay. J. Liu et al., 2017 ). As indicated in reported studies, mollusks ( e.g. , seasnail and bivalve), crustaceans, and fish can be used as bioindicators for heavy metal pollution in different environmental mediums, because these categories accumulate relatively high metal content in their tissues ( Mulayim and Balkıs, 2015 ; Gu et al., 2017 ; Baki et al., 2018 ; Zhelyazkov et al., 2018 ). In this study, the concentrations of each studied metal in the mollusks, crustaceans, and fish in terms of spatial distributions at different sampling sites are presented in Figs. 4, 5, and 6 Some differences were observed among the sampling sites with regards to heavy metal concentrations in mollusks ( Fig. 4 ). To enable the distribution comparable, seasnail, benthic bivalve, and oyster species are separated in the map. The distributions of As, Cd, and Zn concentrations in the seasnails were noticeably high at the sites 12 and 16. A high concentration of Pb was observed at site 2. Concentrations of other metals were not obvious difference in seasnails. Overall, the differences in spatial distributions of heavy metals in benthic bivalves and oyster were not highly clear. Relative high concentration of Cr was observed in the benthic bivalves at site 5, Hg was observed at sites 5 and 15, Ni was observed at sites 4 and 12, and Pb was observed at site 6. High concentrations of Cu and Zn were observed in the oyster at sites 2 and 15. The spatial distributions of heavy metals in the crustaceans are presented in Fig. 5 . At site 4, As and Cd concentrations in the crabs were highest in this study. High Cr concentrations in the crabs were observed at sites 4, 6, and 14. High concentrations of Cu were observed at sites 6 and 8. High Hg concentrations in the crabs were observed at sites 8 and 9. High Ni and Pb concentrations were observed at site 8. The lowest concentration of Zn was observed at site 4, and no obvious differences of heavy metal concentrations in the crabs were observed at other sites. For the studied metals in the shrimps, high levels of As and Pb were observed in Chinese white shrimp ( F. chinensis ) tissues collected from site 4. The Cd, Cu, Hg, Ni, and Zn concentrations in the shrimp at site 10 displayed similar patterns and higher concentrations in mantis shrimp ( O. oratoria ) than that in four whiteleg shrimp ( P. vannamei ) samples. However, the Cr concentration was low in the mantis shrimp at site 10. These results occurred possibly due to the variation in shrimp species and their feeding habits ( Baki et al., 2018 ). Mantis shrimp ( O. oratoria ) is carnivorous and eats benthic crabs, snails, and shellfish using powerful punches. Therefore, the high concentrations of several heavy metals in their tissues possibly resulted from accumulation through trophic transfer. The spatial distributions of heavy metals in the fish are illustrated in Fig. 6 . The concentrations of As in the fish muscles were relatively high at site 16. The highest level of Cd was observed at site 6, and low Cd concentrations were observed at sites 5, 7, and 10. High difference was observed in the distributions of Cr levels in the fish, with high levels at sites 7, 10, 14, and 16, which was mainly because of the benthic living habits of C. abbreviatus , C. macrognathos , and P. modestus . According to the results, Cu and Zn concentrations in the fish did not demonstrate obvious difference. High Hg levels were observed at sites 13 and 6. Highest Ni and Pb levels were observed at site 14. Concentrations of Ni at site 7 and Pb at site 16 were relatively high as presented in the maps. In general, most sampling sites had high concentrations of some selected heavy metals in marine organisms. For tidal flats and sediments indicated by mollusks, high metal level sites were 2, 5, 12, 15, and 16. As indicated by results from the crustaceans, the heavy metal concentrations in the bottom environment were relatively high at sampling sites 4, 6, 8, and 10. The heavy metal concentrations were high in the upper seawater at sites 6, 7, 13, 14, and 16, which was indicated by the fish. In addition to marine environmental pollution, it should be considered that the physiological variations of marine organism species and their living habits result in high levels of heavy metals in organisms. Xiangshan Bay is an important mariculture base located on the coast of the East China Sea, with a large production of raft cultured oyster, cage cultured fish, and beach cultured shellfish ( ). For the heavy metal concentrations in fish, concentrations of almost all of the selected metals including Zn, As, Cu, Hg, Cd, Ni, and Pb were low in the farmed and high in the wild fish ( ). Those findings concurred with previous studies that have proposed growth dilution to explain this phenomenon ( Sun et al., 2014 ). In the present study, we fortunately collected both wild and maricultured samples of oyster ( O. cucullata ) and fish ( M. cephalus ) in Xiangshan Bay. Therefore, heavy metal levels in maricultured and wild organisms were compared in this study. The comparison results indicated that the concentrations of Zn and Cu in the wild oysters were higher than that in raft cultured oysters, and the difference in levels of other metals were not considerably high ( Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Qiu, 2015 ). Growth dilution consists of decrease in pollutant concentrations in organism when the organism grows rapidly. Therefore, growth dilution may regulate heavy metal bioaccumulation in cultured oyster and fish because they generally grow very rapidly compared with the wild. Moreover, the concentrations of many metals in the organism tissues could biomagnify along the food chains, with higher metal levels in organisms on the longer food chains ( Qiu, 2015 ). Cage cultured fish mainly fed on artificial fish pellets and small trash fish and had a relatively short food chain. However, dietary structures for wild fish were highly complex. Thus, heavy metal concentrations were low in the farmed fish and high in wild fish. The food sources for cultured and wild oysters were similar, but wild oysters inhabited the reefs along the coastal areas that often retained relatively high concentrations of heavy metals ( Liu et al., 2018 ). This can be an important factor for the high concentrations of Cu and Zn in wild oyster. The estimated daily intakes (EDIs) represented an estimate of the daily exposure doses of heavy metals for human population through their diets ( Baki et al., 2018 ). To calculate the EDIs, heavy metal concentrations expressed as wet weight in the tissues of six marine species groups were converted according to the moisture content of each sample. The EDIs were calculated using the following formula: EDIs = F × D × I × C W × T where F is the exposure frequency (365 days/year); D is the exposure duration (70 years); I is the ingestion rate of mollusk, crustacean, and fish which considered to be 17.1, 8.3, and 105 g/person/day, respectively, as used in previous studies ( Jiang et al., 2005 ; Guo et al., 2007 ); C is the concentration of heavy metals in the edible tissues expressed as wet weight converted from dry weight (μg/g ww); W is the average body weight (55.9 kg for adults) as used in previous studies ( Hang et al., 2009 ); and T is average time (365 days/year multiplied by the number of exposure years, assuming 70 years in this study). The EDIs of selected heavy metals from seasnail, benthic bivalve, oyster, crab, shrimp, and fish consumption by adults are summarized in Table 2 . The EDIs for most of the studied heavy metals in seasnails and oysters of mollusks were higher than that in crustaceans and fish except for As and Hg, which were highest in fish ( Table 2 ). Those results indicated that the coastal residents were exposed to high doses of Cd, Cr, Cu, Ni, Pb, and Zn from the consumption of mollusks and exposed to high doses of As and Hg from fish consumption. The results were considerably similar to that in our previous study except for Cr, of which the highest EDI was found in fish ( Liu et al., 2018 ). In addition, the permissible provisional tolerable daily intake (PTDI) values for all metals summarized by Mok et al. (2015) from the data of Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency are listed in Table 2 as one of the reference points to assess the hazard risk from the marine organisms consumption. The potential health risks of heavy metals resulting from seafood consumption for coastal people were evaluated according to previously described methods ( Liu et al., 2018 ). As described by the US EPA standard methods, THQ represented the potential non-carcinogenic risk for heavy metals ingested through the oral intake and was expressed as the ratio of the daily oral intake and the oral reference dose (RfDo, US EPA, 2014 ; Q. Liu et al., 2017 ) with the following equations: THQ = EDIs RfDo The RfDo was used as a reference daily exposure dose, to which humans are continually exposed over a lifetime without a considerable risk of carcinogenic effects ( Raknuzzaman et al., 2016 ). In this study, RfDo of selected metals were obtained from the regional screening level summary table ( US EPA, 2014 ), with the exception of Pb ( Hang et al., 2009 ), to assess the EDIs metal risks in marine organisms. The THQ values for individual metals from different marine organism species consumption are presented in . According to the results, the THQ values for most of the studied metals in all of the marine organism species were less than one, with the exception of As. The THQ values for As in all species were more than one, with the highest value of 12.28 in fish. The estimated results of this study indicated potential non-carcinogenic health risk from ingestion of As through consumption of these marine organism species, especially fish. Continuous and excessive fish ingestion could result in chronic non-carcinogenic effects. Authors: Abualhaj N.Z., Dardas Z., Azab B., Ali D., Sughayer M.A., Aladily T.N., Ahram M.
Title: The frequency of NOTCH1 variants in T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma among Jordanian patients
Affiliations: Department of Pathology, Microbiology and Forensic Medicine, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Cell Therapy Center, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Department of Pathology, King Hussein Cancer Center, Amman, Jordan; Department of Physiology and Biochemistry, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan
Authors with affiliations: Abualhaj, N.Z., Department of Pathology, Microbiology and Forensic Medicine, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Dardas, Z., Department of Pathology, Microbiology and Forensic Medicine, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Azab, B., Department of Pathology, Microbiology and Forensic Medicine, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan, Cell Therapy Center, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Ali, D., Cell Therapy Center, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Sughayer, M.A., Department of Pathology, King Hussein Cancer Center, Amman, Jordan; Aladily, T.N., Department of Pathology, Microbiology and Forensic Medicine, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Ahram, M., Department of Physiology and Biochemistry, School of Medicine, The University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan
Abstract: The transmembrane receptor NOTCH1 is thought to be associated with the development and progression of T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL)/T-lymphoblastic lymphoma (T-LBL) and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL). The current study aimed to characterize NOTCH1 expression and elucidate the variants in the functional PEST domain of the receptor in T-ALL/LBL and CLL/SLL. The nuclear expression of NOTCH1 protein was detected in 25% and 5% of cases of T-ALL/LBL and CLL/SLL, respectively, whereas cytoplasmic expression was detected in 33.3% and 15% cases, respectively. The frequency of variants in T-ALL/LBL was 33%, whereas 40% of CLL/SLL cases possessed variants. Four novel variants were identified; three of which were non-synonymous and one common variant c.7280_7280delG between T-ALL/LBL and CLL/SLL cases. The previously described variant, c.7541_7542delCT, was detected in 3 cases of CLL/SLL. These results provide support for the contribution of NOTCH1 in the etiology of these types of cancers. © 2019 Elsevier Inc.
Author Keywords: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia; Jordan; NOTCH1; PEST domain; T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia
